content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act titled "Access to Women's Health Care Act of 1997" highlights the importance of women's health care. Congress acknowledges the historical lack of attention to women's health and recognizes obstetrician-gynecologists as crucial providers of primary and preventive care for women throughout their lifetime. Obstetrician-gynecologists play a vital role in providing primary and preventive care for women, managing their overall health beyond just the reproductive system. They refer patients to other physicians less frequently, saving time and costs. More than 20 states have taken steps to promote women's health care. While over 20 states have promoted access to obstetrician-gynecologists for women's health care, patients in some states or federally-governed health plans still face restrictions. SEC. 2. ASSURING ACCESS TO OBSTETRICAL AND GYNECOLOGICAL SERVICES UNDER GROUP HEALTH PLANS AND INSURANCE COVERAGE by amending the Public Health Service Act to include standards for access to obstetrical and gynecological services. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without requiring prior authorization. This is to ensure access to obstetrical and gynecological services under group health plans and insurance coverage. Group health plans and insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without prior authorization. This ensures access to obstetric and gynecologic care provided by participating physicians, treating the ordering of gynecologic care as prior authorization from the primary care provider. Group health plans and insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without prior authorization. This ensures access to gynecologic care ordered by participating physicians, without waiving coverage requirements for medical necessity or appropriateness. Prohibitions include denying women eligibility for coverage based on gynecologic care. Group health plans cannot deny women eligibility for coverage to avoid requirements, offer incentives to accept less coverage, or penalize providers for following the regulations. The group health plan must comply with notice requirements and can negotiate reimbursement levels with providers. More protective state laws regarding coverage are not preempted. The group health plan can negotiate reimbursement levels with providers for care provided, and more protective state laws regarding coverage are not preempted. STANDARDS RELATING TO ACCESS TO OBSTETRICAL AND GYNECOLOGICAL SERVICES. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without requiring prior authorization from another primary care provider. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without requiring prior authorization for obstetric and gynecologic care. Ordering other gynecologic care by the participating physician is considered as prior authorization from the primary care provider. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow female enrollees to designate an obstetrician-gynecologist as their primary care provider without requiring prior authorization for gynecologic care. The participating physician's order for gynecologic care serves as prior authorization from the primary care provider. Group health plans must not deny women eligibility or coverage renewal to avoid requirements, offer payments to accept less protection, or penalize providers for following the section. Notice of these requirements must be provided. The requirements of this section must be provided to participants or beneficiaries as a material modification in the plan, with notice required within 60 days of the first plan year. This section does not limit reimbursements by group health plans or health insurance. The section allows group health plans to negotiate reimbursement levels with providers for care provided. It does not override state laws that establish standards for health insurance issuers in connection with group health insurance. The section allows group health plans to negotiate reimbursement levels with providers for care provided and does not override state laws that establish standards for health insurance issuers in connection with group health insurance coverage. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act to ensure greater protections for enrollees. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act to ensure greater protections for enrollees, including inserting "sections 711 and 713" in section 732(a) of the Act. Standards relating to access to obstetrical and gynecological services are addressed in section 2752 of the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those for group health plans under ERISA. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to issuers as if they were group health plans. State laws can provide greater protections for enrollees than federal law. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to insurance issuers offering group health insurance coverage with enhanced protections for enrollees starting from January 1, 1998. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting from January 1, 1998, while the amendment made by subsection (b) applies to individual market health insurance coverage on or after that date. Group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act are exempt until a later date. The amendments made by subsection (a) do not apply to group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act until the later of the termination of the agreements or January 1, 1998. Any plan amendment solely to conform to the new requirements is not considered a termination of the collective bargaining agreement.
